review.title: On A Semi-Automatic Method for Generating Composition Tables
review.abstract: Originating from Allen's Interval Algebra, composition-based reasoning has been widely acknowledged as the most popular reasoning technique in qualitative spatial and temporal reasoning. Given a qualitative calculus (i.e. a relation model), the first thing we should do is to establish its composition table (CT). In the past three decades, such work is usually done manually. This is undesirable and error-prone, given that the calculus may contain tens or hundreds of basic relations. Computing the correct CT has been identified by Tony Cohn as a challenge for computer scientists in 1995. This paper addresses this problem and introduces a semi-automatic method to compute the CT by randomly generating triples of elements. For several important qualitative calculi, our method can establish the correct CT in a reasonable short time. This is illustrated by applications to the Interval Algebra, the Region Connection Calculus RCC-8, the INDU calculus, and the Oriented Point Relation Algebras. Our method can also be used to generate CTs for customised qualitative calculi defined on restricted domains.

sections.heading: 3.2 The Oriented Point Relation Algebra
sections.text: In the OPRAm calculation, where m is a parameter characterizing its granularity, two principles of the system are represented (PRAm system), each object is represented as an oriented point (o-point for short) in the plane. Each o-point has an orientation, based on which, 2m − 1 other directions are introduced according to the selected granularity. However, each other o-point is located on a beam or in a section between two consecutive beams and sections, each of these beams and sections is an integer from 0 to 4m − 1. The relative directional information of two o-points A, B is uniformly encoded in a pair of integer numbers (s, t), where s is the beam or section of A where B is located, and t is the beam or section of B where A. sections.heading: 4 Further Discussions
sections.text: In the last section we have applied our algorithm to generate the CTs of IA, INDU, OPRA1, OPRA2 and RCC-8. In this section we will discuss the advantages and disadvantages of our method. The algorithm works very well for simple objects such as points, intervals, rectangles and hard disks, especially in a small subdomain. For a qualitative calculation with less than 100 basic relationships, it can calculate the CT in a few minutes. We also consider larger calculations. The oriented point relation algebras OPRA3 and OPRA4 each have 156 and 272 basic relationships. Applying our algorithm to an appropriate polar coordinated subdomain Dp (M2), 261,576 and 1,082,752 c-triads, which we found in a few hours each, coinciding with those.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusion
sections.text: The described method is a very natural approach, and a similar idea has been used to derive composition tables for elaboration of RCC with convexity [21] and for ternary direction calculation [22]. The table calculated in [22] is complete, but its completeness is guaranteed by manual verification of all geometric configurations fulfilling the table. Besides these two works, very little attention has been paid to this natural approach in the literature on composition tables. We think that a systematic investigation is necessary to discover both the strong and weak points of this approach. We implemented the basic algorithm for several well-known qualitative calculations, including the interval algebra, INDU, OPRAm for m = 1-4 and RCC-8. Our experiments suggest that the proposed method for calculation of the Qi region is very good, but not based on Qi calculation.
